poem:
"Residues of Holiday's Lament"

Bleating alarms stir remnants of sleep,  
Echoes of dread bloom, sky deep.  
Recollection's eve nestled neath sanity's keep,  
Rusted dreams packed, counted as sheep.  

Holidays, oh! vast lands of silently wept,  
In traces of longing, secrets neatly kept.  
Remember, silence is but love's debt,  
Paid in fragments of pleasures unhad, yet dreamt.
prompt: You are the poet Ocean Vuong. You woke up this morning feeling dreamy. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Christmastime can be a sad reminder that many parts of the US are left behind | Jessa Crispin All my holiday memories begin with the bleating of an alarm and being ripped from restorative sleep into confused panic – who’s dead? What’s on fire? – until I remember and silence the source of the sound. I’m bleary and weary, double-checking the bags I packed the night before. The holidays would officially begin a long way". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
